text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.17.2, Compliance Initiative Projects, Responsibilities.
This revision incorporates the following signiﬁcant changes:
a. IRM
–Outlined where CIP coordinators report. Separated SB/SE, LB&I and speciﬁc duties. Added classiﬁcation of returns as a duty. b. IRM
–Changed section to reﬂect only SB/SE HQ CIP Analyst duties. c. IRM
–Added W&I and TE/GE. d. IRM
–Added LB&I CP&A Manager duties. e. IRM
–Updated LB&I CIP Oversight Committee role. f. IRM
–Added LB&I Risk Identiﬁcation Control Board duties. g. IRM
–Clariﬁed Disclosure Office is only required to be involved when sharing data with third parties. h. IRM
–Added TE/GE Research duties. i. IRM
–Clariﬁed a Director only authorizes CIP’s within their own function, cross-functional.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 4.17.2 dated 02-25-2010 is superseded.
Compliance employees within all Operating Divisions.
Table of Contents
CIP Coordinators will be assigned to the following groups:
The CIP Coordinator’s duties include:
Reviewing CIPs for content and ensure all appropriate individuals have approved and concurred with the CIP. See IRM
, Review, Concurrence and Approval Part One CIP Only, IRM
, LB&I Review Concurrence and Approval, IRM

, Review, Concur- rence and Approval for Part II Authorization Requests. Classifying CIP returns where appropriate. Assigning project codes, tracking codes, freeze codes and aging reason codes for monitoring purposes when applicable. Preparing CIP authorization requests, status reports, and termination reports to ensure requirements are met. See IRM
, Research of Existing Data, Similar Projects, IRM
, Part One CIP Authoriza- tion Request and IRM

, Part Two CIP Authorization Request. Providing guidance, assistance, oversight, and monitoring for all CIP activity within the exam operating unit to ensure actions are completed timely, procedures are followed, and objectives are met. Ensuring data used to develop the project is clearly identiﬁed, available, and evaluated for accuracy. Establishing returns and ensuring the sample does not exceed size limi- tations. Ensuring data is timely returned or disposed of properly when the project is terminated. Note: This is related to data for returns less than status
Cases built and placed in the audit pipeline in status
or greater, do not need to be returned to PSP. See IRM
, Extension of a Project and IRM
, Project Termination and Report
This is related to data for returns less than status
Cases built and placed in the audit pipeline in status
or greater, do not need to be returned to PSP. See IRM
, Extension of a Project and IRM
, Project Termination and Report regarding audits after project completion date and/or termination.
Maintaining ROTERS for each project and provide metrics for status reports, termination reports, and special reports when necessary.
4.17 Compliance Initiative Projects
Monitoring progress on projects and report issues or concerns to the appropriate management per IRM

), CIP Coordinator. Ensuring technical issues have been coordinated with Appeals and Counsel, if appropriate, and results are documented in the authorization request. When required or appropriate, coordinating workload identiﬁcation and delivery with the other divisional analysts. Analyzing CIP inventory using the CIP Data Overview Report (DOR).

Note: This report is for monitoring CIP progress and results. It can be used to analyze the compliance risk of the issue identiﬁed by CIP using business metrics such as no change rate and ments. Review of the report may provide indicators a CIP reﬁned, terminated or expanded. It is recommended this report be reviewed regularly as part of the monitoring process. TE/GE will use established monitoring reports for these purposes.
Forwarding a signed copy of the CIP to all parties once the CIP is ﬁnal/ approved.

Securing a signed, completed Workload Selection Form from the CIP Contact/Project Coordinator. Coordinating with the LB&I CIP Headquarters Analyst to ensure the LB&I Oversight Committee considers the CIP when applicable. Ensuring both the LB&I CIP Headquarters Analyst and CP&A Manager review and sign off on the CIP prior to presenting the CIP to the LB&I CIP Oversight Committee.
The SB/SE CIP Headquarter Analyst duties will include:

Reviewing CIPs for content and ensure all appropriate individuals have approved or concurred with the CIP. Providing guidance, assistance, oversight, and monitoring for all SB/SE CIP activity to ensure actions are completed timely, procedures are followed, and objectives are met. Maintaining ROTERS for each project and make them available for status reports, termination reports, and special reports when necessary. Conducting periodic teleconferences with CIP coordinators, and follow up with questions on outstanding CIP issues.
Note: The National CIP Database should be reviewed periodically (with a minimum of one review per year).
Maintaining the CIP program’s web presence (SharePoint site, etc.).
page 3

Designating a CIP Coordinator who will report to said manager or designee. Reviewing CIP authorization requests, status reports, and termination reports to ensure CIPs are consistent with procedures and Service policies. Reviewing CIP authorization requests, status reports, and termination reports to ensure proper coordination has occurred and agreement been reached with all signiﬁcantly impacted functions or units, and activities can be accomplished within the necessary time frames. Ensuring proper alternative treatments are included in the request. Conducting annual reviews of the CIP process.
The duties of managers and/or directors of functions or units signiﬁcantly impacted by the CIP include:
Providing information for the preparation of the project authorization, if requested. Timely reviewing project authorizations to ensure time frames are rea
sonable, resources are available when needed, and actions are completed according to schedule.
The duties of managers and/or directors from the (CSO) function include:
4.17.2.6 (02-25-2010) Communications and Stakeholder Outreach (CSO) Managers/Directors
Coordinating with the function/unit that originates the project to determine what involvement by CSO is appropriate.
Providing information for the preparation of project authorization, if requested.
Timely reviewing authorization requests to ensure CSO time frames reasonable and resources can be available when needed.
Providing guidance and suggestions on alternative treatments.

Providing oversight direction and review to ensure guidelines and dures are followed. Providing data and special assistance if requested by the originating function. Ensuring workload selection methods proposed by the CIP are consis
tent with established IRS policy and procedure. Reviewing expired CIP’s and report out on CIP results and any useful workload selection methods/issues for future use.
Compliance Initiative (

) The CIP Oversight Committee consists of LB&I Executive/Directors. It two levels: The Directors of Field Operations (DFO’s) and the Executive CIP Oversight nance Board (EGB). Each level of the committee meets monthly and is responsible for providing guidance and making decisions with regards to operations. The LB&I CIP Oversight Committee responsibilities include: • Reviewing and make recommendation on approval for all CIPs. • Reviewing and approve extensions, modiﬁcations and terminations. • Determining if a CIP affects another division and will require concurrence/approval. • Documenting decisions and share information with affected parties appropriate channels. (

) The duties of RICB are to ensure resources are used effectively, assist in cating CP&A resources and managing the suite of risk identiﬁcation Risk Identiﬁcation RICB participates in the CP&A review of CIP requests and considers the Board (RICB) following factors: • Alignment of risk being addressed with organizational priorities. • Consistency with risk identiﬁcation strategy and available resources. • Likelihood of success. (
) The duties of the HQ disclosure policy analyst include reviewing CIP tion requests to ensure they comply with privacy, security, and disclosure Disclosure Policy requirements. (

) Disclosure is only required to be involved when the CIP will involve sharing internal taxpayer information with the third parties. Receiving data from parties alone does not require involvement from the HQ disclosure policy analyst. (

) The duties of the SB/SE Finance Research and Strategy (FR&S) function TE/GE Research include providing data and special assistance (for Function developing measures, developing methodology, providing statistical or other analysis, etc.) if requested by the originating function. (
) The duties of the Director, Exam Case Selection and respective TE/GE tional Director include: Exam Case • Approving all CIPs within or involving their Operating Unit as and TE/GE IRM
, Review, Concurrence and Approval of Part One CIP Director (EO, Only or IRM
, Review, Concurrence and Approval for Part GE/SS) Authorization Requests. • Setting divisional standards and policies for the authorization and mentation of CIPs. (

) The Director or designee will: • Provide oversight direction and review to ensure guidelines and dures are followed. • Provide assistance to the ﬁeld offices if needed. • Keep ﬁeld functions informed about new issues, current projects,
